articles.headline: To Save Money, States Turn to Furloughs
articles.snippet: At least 15 states are in various stages of considering or implementing furloughs.
articles.abstract: At least 15 states are in various stages of considering or implementing furloughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Licenses for same-sex marriages were supposed to be issued in Iowa starting this Friday. But because of a crimped state budget, court employees will be on mandatory furlough that day and the courts will be closed. Gay couples cannot start filing for their licenses until Monday.

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Seek a Chrysler Plan for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department has reached an agreement in principle with the autoworkers union in the event that Chrysler, which is negotiating with Fiat, files for bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department has reached an agreement in principle with the autoworkers union in the event that Chrysler, which is negotiating with Fiat, files for bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Treasury Department is directing Chrysler to prepare a Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing as soon as next week, people with direct knowledge of the talks said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Microsoft Profit Falls for First Time in 23 Years
articles.snippet: The company’s revenue dropped 6 percent and its profits by 32 percent compared with the same quarter last year.
articles.abstract: The company’s revenue dropped 6 percent and its profits by 32 percent compared with the same quarter last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fresh off one of the worst quarters in company history, Microsoft offered investors little evidence that a beleaguered personal computer market would recover anytime soon.

articles.headline: Subprime Loans, Corporate-Style, Will Fuel Defaults
articles.snippet: A record percentage of senior debt is on the lowest rungs of credit quality, making conditions favorable for the default rate on corporate loans and bonds to skyrocket in the near future.
articles.abstract: A record percentage of senior debt is on the lowest rungs of credit quality, making conditions favorable for the default rate on corporate loans and bonds to skyrocket in the near future.
articles.lead_paragraph: The loans went to borrowers who might never before have been allowed to borrow. When they found repayment difficult, they were permitted to refinance their loans, generating fees for the lenders and postponing the ultimate reckoning. Then the credit markets turned and both the borrowers and lenders were in deep trouble.

articles.headline: Tracking Loans Through a Firm That Holds Millions
articles.snippet: MERS holds 60 million mortgages on homes in the U.S., and its name has been arising on foreclosure notices, raising questions about a process that obscures the path of mortgage ownership.
articles.abstract: MERS holds 60 million mortgages on homes in the U.S., and its name has been arising on foreclosure notices, raising questions about a process that obscures the path of mortgage ownership.
articles.lead_paragraph: Judge Walt Logan had seen enough. As a county judge in Florida, he had 28 cases pending in which an entity called MERS wanted to foreclose on homeowners even though it had never lent them any money.

articles.headline: Edgy Banks Start to Get Word Today on Stress Tests
articles.snippet: The nation’s 19 biggest banks will start learning Friday how they fared in federal examinations — and which among them will need another bailout.
articles.abstract: The nation’s 19 biggest banks will start learning Friday how they fared in federal examinations — and which among them will need another bailout.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street is stressed out about stress tests.

articles.headline: U.S. Role Questioned on Merrill
articles.snippet: Newly revealed testimony is raising questions about whether federal regulators overstepped their bounds in pressing Bank of America’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: Newly revealed testimony is raising questions about whether federal regulators overstepped their bounds in pressing Bank of America’s acquisition of Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Newly revealed testimony about federal involvement in the Bank of America acquisition of Merrill Lynch is raising questions about whether bank regulators may have overstepped during a period of extreme stress in the financial system.

articles.headline: Plight of Carmakers Could Upset All Pension Plans
articles.snippet: Pension experts predict that a government takeover of the plans at G.M. and Chrysler would spur other auto companies and all types of manufacturers to abandon such benefits for competitive reasons.
articles.abstract: Pension experts predict that a government takeover of the plans at G.M. and Chrysler would spur other auto companies and all types of manufacturers to abandon such benefits for competitive reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Decisions that the government will make soon on the future of General Motors and Chrysler could accelerate the decline of traditional pension plans, which have sheltered generations of workers from an impoverished old age.

articles.headline: Obama Resisting Push for Interrogation Panel
articles.snippet: President Obama told Democratic leaders that a full inquiry would steal energy from his agenda.
articles.abstract: President Obama told Democratic leaders that a full inquiry would steal energy from his agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House and the Democratic leadership in the Senate signaled on Thursday that they would block for now any effort to establish an independent commission to investigate the Bush administration’s approval of harsh interrogation techniques.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Storm of Violence in Iraq Strains Its Security Forces
articles.snippet: Two bombings at Baghdad’s most revered Shiite shrine brought the death toll over 24 hours to nearly 150.
articles.abstract: Two bombings at Baghdad’s most revered Shiite shrine brought the death toll over 24 hours to nearly 150.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A deadly outburst of violence appears to be overwhelming Iraq’s police and military forces as American troops hand over greater control of cities across the country to them. On Friday, twin suicide bombings killed at least 60 people outside Baghdad’s most revered Shiite shrine, pushing the death toll in one 24-hour period to nearly 150.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Sam Dagher

articles.headline: At Ford, a Sense of Survival Despite the Losses Piling Up
articles.snippet: Ford’s decision to borrow money years ago is helping it weather major losses, like $1.4 billion in the latest quarter.
articles.abstract: Ford’s decision to borrow money years ago is helping it weather major losses, like $1.4 billion in the latest quarter.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The Ford Motor Company unleashed a torrent of dismal financial numbers Friday, saying that it lost $1.4 billion, sales fell 43 percent and it spent $3.7 billion of its cash during the first quarter.
articles.byline: By Nick Bunkley and Bill Vlasic
